body_html:
@gunan I apologize that I didn't rename the title after my discovery that nothing from Tensorflow is actually working.

I'd recommend you to also familiarize yourself with the Tensorflow Guide. Ever since v1.10, it is possible to import tensorflow.keras using, and I quote from the above link,

import tensorflow as tf
from tensorflow import keras

There was an issue sometime ago discussing tf.keras is simply too frustrating to use.

Furthermore, just test this before you recommend anything, I can see that the below works fine on macOS with pip (I'm using pyenv to isolate all my Python packages and versions):

pip install tensorflow==1.11.0rc1
python3.5 -c "import tensorflow.keras"

Have a read on my further information comment just above yours.

from tensorflow import keras

There was an issue sometime ago discussing tf.keras is simply too frustrating to use.
Furthermore, just test this before you recommend anything, I can see that the below works fine on macOS with pip (I'm using pyenv to isolate all my Python packages and versions):

Have a read on my further information comment just above yours.
body:
@gunan I apologize that I didn't rename the title after my discovery that *nothing from Tensorflow is actually working*.

I'd recommend you to also familiarize yourself with the [Tensorflow Guide](https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/keras). Ever since v1.10, it **is** possible to import `tensorflow.keras` using, and I quote from the above link,
```
import tensorflow as tf
from tensorflow import keras
```
There was an issue sometime ago discussing `tf.keras` is simply too frustrating to use.

Furthermore, just test this before you recommend anything, I can see that the below works fine on macOS with pip (I'm using pyenv to isolate all my Python packages and versions):
```
pip install tensorflow==1.11.0rc1
python3.5 -c "import tensorflow.keras"
```

Have a read on my [further information comment](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/22445#issuecomment-423619601) just above yours.
